snippet: The death of an innocent bystander has left the city wondering how what the police said was a petty turf war between “crews” of children could breed such random, deadly violence.
abstract: Murder of an innocent bystander by 14-year-old Brooklyn student Kahton Anderson leaves New York City wondering how petty turf war between 'crews' of children could breed such random, deadly violence; although city's murder rate has dropped sharply, police say clashes between teenage crews, mini-gangs that grow out of blocks or housing projects, now account for 30 percent of all shootings.

byline.contributor: J. David Goodman, Michael Schwirtz and Julie Turkewitz contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The death of an innocent bystander has left the city wondering how what the police said was a petty turf war between “crews” of children could breed such random, deadly violence.

headline.main: An 8th Grader, a Gun and a Bus Rider in the Way
headline.print_headline: An 8th Grader, a Gun and a Bus Rider in the Way
